Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>One problem I see with all economic prediction is that it is
>impossible to predict human ideas, yet ideas are major factors in
>economic activity.   What is going to be invented next year?  How can
>we know whether someone will come up with an ingenious marketing idea
>at an otherwise lackluster company?  Other human initiatives like
>deciding to take on a rival or even war also are frequently almost
>impossible to predict until it's too late (at least too late to make
>an economic gain from the prediction).  Accurately predicting the
>ideas and initiatives that various individuals will come up is perhaps
>as difficult as the problem of AI itself, since it would require
>accurately simulating the thought processes leading up to the
>decisions.
>
>Of course, not to be too pessimistic, there are still some trends that
>can be followed with a level of success, but I just don't think
>there's ever going to be an extremely accurate prediction model.
>  
>
{Idea] Many stock price movements are unpredictable, but some of the 
movements may be predictable after effects of the unpredictable moves. 
Therefore the key in making money would be to be ability to determine 
when the predictable movements are occuring (or are about to occur) and 
to trade based on the prediction, and to ignore all other 
non-predictable movements. Therefore something akin to a confidence 
output would probably be a good thing, so instead of always trying to 
predict tomorrows price the network has the ability to admit that it 
doesn't 'understand' the current conditions and therefore won't be 
making a prediction today.

Colin.
